description:
MW polyomavirus, also known as Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV), is a small, non-enveloped DNA virus that belongs to the Polyomaviridae family. It was first discovered in 2008 and is the primary causative agent of Merkel cell carcinoma, a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer.

The viral genome of MW polyomavirus is a circular, double-stranded DNA molecule of approximately 5.4 kilobase pairs. The viral genome encodes several proteins, including the large T antigen and small T antigen, which play crucial roles in the viral replication process and the transformation of host cells.

MW polyomavirus is primarily transmitted through close personal contact, and it is estimated that a large proportion of the human population is asymptomatically infected with the virus. However, in individuals with compromised immune systems or other risk factors, the virus can contribute to the development of Merkel cell carcinoma, a highly aggressive and often fatal form of skin cancer.

The study of MW polyomavirus has provided valuable insights into the mechanisms of viral carcinogenesis and has implications for the development of diagnostic tools, targeted therapies, and preventive strategies for Merkel cell carcinoma.
